awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Electron-Beam Lithography Tool for Research, Education and Training
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a state-of-the-art Electron-Beam Lithography (EBL) tool to meet the nanoscale research and teaching needs of the University of Pennsylvania and its academic and industrial neighbors in the Mid-Atlantic region. The EBL instrument enables a wide range of materials and devices to be patterned on the scale of tens of nanometers. The capabilities of this advanced instrument are central to advancing research at the forefront of diverse science and engineering disciplines, including the fundamental exploration of the behavior of charge, spin, light, heat, and motion with applications in photonics and electronics, quantum computation and communication, wearable and implantable health monitoring, micro- and macro-scale energy technologies, and chemo-/bio- and motion sensing. Participating faculty members use the EBL system in educational and outreach activities to broaden participation from underrepresented groups in science and engineering. Undergraduate and graduate students in the engineering and science disciplines will gain valuable research experience and practical knowledge in nanofabrication techniques. The instrument is housed in the Quattrone Nanofabrication Facility, a multi-user research and training facility within the Singh Center for Nanotechnology at the University of Pennsylvania and home to the Mid-Atlantic Nanotechnology Hub (MANTH), an NSF National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI) site. 

The EBL system is equipped with a dynamic clock for multipass exposure with high-fidelity programmable writing order control, which enables high-throughput, high placement accuracy, high-dose resolution accuracy to pattern structures with nanometer-scale features and desired complexity. The instrument is essential to developing innovative methods to structure materials into architectures for a broad range of topics: photonic and plasmonic light emitters, topological photonic and quantum logical gates, and integrated photonics for high capacity information transmission and processing; quantum materials with exotic band structures for dynamically tunable electronic, optoelectronic, and sensing devices; oxide and halide perovskites with intriguing ferro-, piezo-, and pyro-electricity and the manipulation of their nanoscale interfaces for novel structure and physical properties; large-scale ultralow weight, robust mechanical metamaterials; and 2D to 3D foldable structures of interest for micro- and nano-scale robots, resonators, and sensors. This high-impact research has applications that span computing, communication, health, food-energy-water security, national security, to human-machine interfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on acquiring and installing a state-of-the-art electron-beam lithography (EBL) tool (EBPG 5200) at the Quattrone Nanofabrication Facility (QNF) within the Singh Center for Nanotechnology at the University of Pennsylvania. The installation of this EBL system has not only advanced cutting-edge research across several scientific disciplines but also enhanced educational outreach in nanotechnology and related fields.

 

The primary intellectual contribution of this project lies in its ability to enable the creation of nanometer-scale structures with unmatched precision, opening new avenues for research in quantum optics, material science, and mechanical metamaterials. Through the use of the EBL system, we have significantly advanced the ability to fabricate intricate photonic and plasmonic structures with a high degree of accuracy, paving the way for innovations in optical communications, quantum computing, and integrated devices. This tool has been pivotal in the research of 2D materials, topological materials, and perovskites, all of which demonstrate new optoelectronic properties. Additionally, the EBL system has proven essential in the development of mechanical metamaterials, contributing to the progress of micro- and nano-scale robotics and sensor technologies. The EBL tool has facilitated precise patterning of new quantum materials, allowing for the demonstration of dynamically tunable electronic and optoelectronic devices. These advances are of significant importance to the fields of quantum optics, photonics, and materials science. As a result, the EBL tool has catalyzed numerous high-impact discoveries and will continue to shape future research in these areas for years to come.


This project has had a far-reaching impact not only in advancing scientific knowledge but also in fostering broader societal benefits through education, outreach, and collaboration. The EBL system has supported research for 16 faculty members across multiple universities, including collaborations with both academic and industrial researchers. This extensive use of the tool has resulted in innovations that contribute to the development of more efficient and sustainable technologies, such as improved photovoltaic devices and new materials for electronic applications. In terms of education and outreach, the project has provided hands-on learning opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. Students have been trained to operate the EBL system, gaining practical experience in nanoscale fabrication techniques that are vital for their future careers in science and engineering. Additionally, workshops and training sessions have been held for Penn students as well as members of the broader community, allowing individuals to gain insight into the cutting-edge work being done in nanotechnology. The project has also been instrumental in introducing high school and undergraduate students from underrepresented minorities (URMs) to the world of nanotechnology. Visitors from surrounding schools have been brought in to learn about the potential of the EBL system and its applications in various research fields. These educational efforts are part of a broader initiative to promote diversity and inclusion in STEM, particularly in nanotechnology and materials science.

 

The successful acquisition and installation of the EBL system at the Quattrone Nanofabrication Facility have had a transformative effect on both research and education. The tool has enabled significant advancements in multiple fields, including quantum optics, material science, and mechanical metamaterials, while also providing invaluable educational experiences for students and researchers. By continuing to support interdisciplinary research and offering outreach opportunities to diverse communities, this project has demonstrated its lasting impact on both the scientific community and society at large.
